articles.title: Smoke from Canadian wildfires hits air quality across U.S. Midwest and Northeast
articles.author: Evan Bush
articles.summary: The fire season is off to a roaring start in Canada. About 8.6 million acres have burned so far. The area burned is already well above Canada's seasonal average. The pace of burning in Canada is similar to 2023, which was the worst year for smoke exposure in modern U.S. history.

articles.title: Rapid urbanization, deforestation have intensified hot weather
articles.summary: During May and June, temperatures in northern India exceed 40 degrees Celsius. The higher temperatures in urban areas are due to absorption, later re-radiation and heat generation from concrete and stone built up areas. In the past, incoming solar energy was absorbed by soil, used by vegetation for photosynthesis and transpiration, or consumed in evaporation from water bodies. Today, growing concrete expanses reflect and reradiate much of the energy, pushing up the effective temperature further. ACs expel hot exhaust, contributing to local warming, and UV radiation intensifies the blazing sunshine.

articles.title: Earth's CO2 levels reach highest point in millions of years
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: The concentration of carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere has reached a record 430.2 parts per million (ppm) at the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii. The reading marks an increase of 3.5 ppm from May 2024, when the level stood at 426.7 ppm. Scientists attribute the steady rise in carbon dioxide directly to the burning of fossil fuels.

articles.title: Caribbean Regional Fisheries Mechanism shares tools for reducing risk of loss during hurricane season
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: Caribbean Regional Fisheries Mechanism (CRFM) offers a suite of tools and strategies aimed at reducing the risk of loss during hurricane season. Hurricane Joaquin in 2015 caused over $100 million in damages, including $20 million to the fishing fleet. Hurricane Dorian in 2019 caused estimated damages of $3.4 billion in The Bahamas. CRFM has developed and promotes various tools and guidelines that help fishers, communities, and authorities bolster resilience against hurricanes.

articles.title: WVEMD suggest disaster supply kits as hurricane season arrives
articles.summary: Experts tell us not to discount the impact of hurricane season on our communities. The region is nowhere near the ocean, but experts warn against discounting the impact on communities from the hurricane season, which is very unpredictable.      Â

articles.title: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: This year's wildfire season in Canada is shaping up to be the second-worst on record. Wildfires have scorched 3.7 million hectares across the country so far. About 76 per cent of the total area burned is in Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. About 500 firefighters from the United States and Australia are helping out, while another dozen American firefighters are on their way and a federal agency is looking to request 100 more from Costa Rica. International leaders are meeting at the G7 summit in Alberta next week.

articles.title: Trump, in Oval Office, says 2025 hurricane season is FEMA's last
articles.author: Alan Wooten
articles.summary: President Trump wants to bring FEMA back to the state level, like the Department of Education, following the 2025 hurricane season. The 38th week of recovery from Hurricane Helene is beginning for western North Carolina, and it's time to wean off of FEMA.

articles.title: Warmer weather expected to worsen wildfire conditions in Manitoba
articles.author: Kurt Black
articles.summary: There are two large fires burning on the Manitoba-Winnipeg border. The area surrounding the town of Flin Flon remains the province's largest blaze, last measured at over 300,000 hectares. In recent days, rain has come to the area near Pukatawagan, creating the potential for what is called a 'Giga-fire', a new term used to describe infernos that have engulfed over 400,00 hectares.

articles.title: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: Steve Berard
articles.summary: This year's wildfire season in Canada is shaping up to be the second-worst on record. Wildfires have scorched 3.7 million hectares across the country so far. About 76 per cent of the burned area is in Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. About 500 firefighters from the United States and Australia are helping out, while another dozen American firefighters are on their way and a federal agency is looking to request 100 more from Costa Rica. International leaders are set to meet at the G7 summit in Alberta next week.

articles.title: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: This year's wildfire season in Canada is shaping up to be the second-worst on record. Wildfires have scorched 3.7 million hectares across the country so far. About 76 per cent of the burned area is in Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. The Kananaskis Wildfire Charter will be presented at the G7 summit in Alberta next week.

articles.title: This week in science: humans' unique breathing, droughts and the diets of dinosaurs
articles.summary: Regina Barber and Rachel Carlson talk about humans' breathing patterns, how a hotter planet worsens droughts and the diets of dinosaurs on NPR member station KPBX 91.1, KPBZ 90.3, and KSFC 91.9.

articles.title: This week in science: humans' unique breathing, droughts and the diets of dinosaurs
articles.summary: Regina Barber and Rachel Carlson of Short Wave talk about humans' breathing patterns, how a hotter planet worsens droughts, and the diets of dinosaurs on Public Radio for Eastern North Carolina 89.3 WTEB New Bern 88.5 WZNB New Bern 91,5 WBJD Atlantic Beach 90,3 WKNS Kinston 88,5 WHYC Swan Quarter 89,9 W210CF Greenville.

articles.title: This week in science: humans' unique breathing, droughts and the diets of dinosaurs
articles.summary: Regina Barber and Rachel Carlson talk about humans' breathing patterns, how a hotter planet worsens droughts, and the diets of dinosaurs. Listen at 90.3 FM in the Quad Cities, 95.9 FM in Dubuque and on the WVIK app!

articles.title: Federal politics: Australia 'alarmed' by Israel strike on Iran, Penny Wong says — as it happened
articles.author: Joshua Boscaini
articles.summary: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australia is "alarmed" by the escalation in tensions between Israel and Iran. Take a look back at the day's coverage of the situation in Israel and in Iran here.    .     Â

articles.title: Climate change is causing more brutally hot summer days in the Mountain West, analysis finds
articles.author: Kunr Public Radio
articles.summary: In 1970, most cities didn't feel brutally hot summer days strongly influenced by the buildup of man-made carbon pollution. Now, on average, cities are experiencing six extremely hot days each summer. Some cities in the Mountain West are averaging more than twice that amount. In 2023, a record 2,325 people died from heat in the U.S. alone.

articles.title: Long, potholed road to recovery, say Hunter councils assessing flood damage
articles.summary: The tally of damage to public infrastructure continues in the wake of recent flood events, as Hunter residents are warned it's going to be a long road to recovery. The damage to infrastructure is estimated to be in the region of $1.5 million. The recovery is expected to take some time.

articles.title: Canada's wildfire season on track to be the second worst on record
articles.author: Mark Ramzy
articles.summary: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's second-worst on record, federal officials say. About 3.7 million hectares of land have burned so far in Canada. It's only second at this point of the wildfire season to the devastating 2023 fires during which 15 million hectares were ravaged and 200,000 Canadians were forced to flee.

articles.title: Here's Why Canada Is Under A New U.S. Travel Advisory
articles.author: Alexa Leung
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of State has issued a Level 1 travel advisory for Canada due to a growing wildfire season. U.s. citizens are encouraged to 'exercise normal precautions in Canada' as the wildfire season continues to burn. Canadians are welcome to 'take normal security measures' when travelling to the United States.

articles.title: Philippines had record-breaking temperatures
articles.author: Gayan Abeykoon
articles.summary: The Philippines experienced extreme weather events due to human-induced climate change in 2024. January and February saw extreme rainfall in eastern Mindanao, which caused significant flooding and a landslide which killed 93. Extreme heat seared the Philippines most significantly in April, when 19 cars caught fire at the NAIA parking lot due to a grass fire. On April 27, a 38.8C temperature was observed at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport, which also happens to be the highest temperature on record for a site in Metro Manila. There were 6 typhoons that battered the Philippines in 4 weeks between October and November, with more than 1.4 million people displaced.

articles.title: CITIES IN PERIL: Boomtowns built on melting ground
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: As of 2017, nearly 5 million people lived in permafrost zones in and around the Arctic Circle, including major urban centres like Norilsk and Yakutsk. Since 1970, northern Russia has seen temperatures rise by over 3°C. In 2020, the Siberian town of Verkhoyansk registered 38°C, the highest temperature ever recorded in the Arctic. Permafrost thaw is one of the top 10 emerging environmental threats.

articles.title: This could be Canada's 2nd-worst wildfire season
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: This year's fire season has seen wildfires consume 3.7 million hectares, six times the area of Prince Edward Island. The 10-year average for wildfire seasons by this time in June is about 800,000 hectares. Environment and Climate Change Canada is forecasting higher-than-normal temperatures across the country through August.

articles.title: Canada's 2025 wildfire season setting up to be second worst on record
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: The area burned by wildfires so far this season is the second-largest on record in Canada. The greatest fire danger in July is expected to be in southern British Columbia, while the Northwest Territories and Yukon will face an increased risk of wildfires. This year's fire season has seen wildfires consume 3.7 million hectares, six times the area of Prince Edward Island.

articles.title: Canada's 2025 wildfire season setting up to be second worst on record
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: The area burned by wildfires so far this season is the second-largest on record in Canada. This year's fire season has seen wildfires consume 3.7 million hectares. The 10-year average for wildfire seasons is about 800,000 hectares. Environment and Climate Change Canada is forecasting higher-than-normal temperatures across the country through August.

articles.title: World's Ocean surface temperature hits 2nd highest level ever recorded
articles.author: Alimat Aliyeva
articles.summary: The average surface temperature of the world's oceans in May 2025 was 20.79°C, just 0.14°C lower than the record temperature of May 2024. The oceans absorb 25-30% of CO2 released into the atmosphere and 90% of excess heat from the atmosphere. Scientists warn that continued warming could lead to catastrophic changes in marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Arctic sounds another warning on climate
articles.summary: Arctic heatwave has hit historical highs due to climate change. Greenland's ice sheet melted 17 times the normal rate last month. The imperative for urgent climate action was clear a decade ago, which got the global community to sign the Paris accord. Now, even elementary agreements on actions and responsibilities lie in tatters, with Donald Trump playing spoiler.

articles.title: Coast Flood Impacts Masas Vineyard
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: Coastal flooding poses an increasing threat to island communities as sea levels rise. Many cities are updating flood and wetland ordinances to address current and future flood risks. NOAA reports a record number of high-tide flooding days in coastal communities in the United States in 2023.

articles.title: New KCC hurricane model certified
articles.author: David Fox
articles.summary: Karen Clark & Company's US Hurricane Reference Model Version 5.0 has been certified by the Florida Commission on Hurricane Loss Projection Methodology (FCHLPM). It is the industry's benchmark for evaluating model assumptions and methodologies. The latest update incorporates two additional years of climate data to remain up to date with the most recent changes in hurricane activity.

articles.title: Another Study Indicates China Was 7°C Warmer Than Today Throughout Much Of The Holocene
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Today's Gahai lake surface temperature is 9.4°C, similar to the region's documented meteorological station temperatures (8.8°C May-September). The reconstruction's average Gahi Lake sediment warm season temperatures dating to 8000 to 3500 years ago was 16.5°C. Sea levels were 1.8 – 2.3 m higher from 8600 to 6100 years ago.

articles.title: Seattle nights are getting hotter
articles.author: Isabella Breda
articles.summary: Last weekend Seattle-Tacoma International Airport recorded a high of 90 degrees. Last weekend's heat brought the hottest June 8 in the Seattle area since 1948. Seattle's recent warmer-than-normal nights were made three to five times more likely because of climate change, according to Climate Central. Summer nighttime temperatures have warmed on average by about 3 degrees since 1970.

articles.title: Taming the Silent Killer
articles.author: Sandip Tanu Mandal
articles.summary: 2014 was the warmest year in India since 1901. More than 700 people died due to heatstroke and extreme heat in India in 2024. McKinsey study estimated that disruptions in outdoor working hours could impact 4.5% of India's GDP by 2030. The poor and the labourers bear the direct brunt of the heatwaves. Short-term measures, such as occupational cooling arrangements for vulnerable people during heatwaves and better fire management are needed.

articles.title: 'Lukewarming' challenges the climate change narrative: A new perspective on global warming
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: Patrick J. Michaels and Paul C. Knappenberger's book "Lukewarming" presents a moderate view of global warming. The authors propose the term "lukewarming" to describe a more gradual and less alarming warming trend. The book examines the bias toward alarmism in the scientific community, driven by the need for funding and media attention. They argue that the Paris Agreement is more about politics than science.

articles.title: Salakope: Hope restored as gov't awards contract for continuation of Blekusu sea defense project
articles.author: Modern Ghana
articles.summary: Amandi Construction Firm has been awarded a contract for the continuation of the Blekusu Sea Defense Project. The project will protect the coastal environment, promote economic development, and improve the quality of life for the residents of Salakope, Agavedzi, Amutsinu and surrounding communities along the coast.

articles.title: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: Nick Murray
articles.summary: This year's fire season has seen wildfires consume 3.7 million hectares, six times the area of Prince Edward Island. The 10-year average for wildfire seasons is about 800,000 hectares. Environment and Climate Change Canada is forecasting higher-than-normal temperatures across the country through August.

articles.title: 2025 wildfire season on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: This year's fire season has seen wildfires consume 3.7 million hectares, six times the area of Prince Edward Island. The 10-year average for wildfire seasons is about 800,000 hectares. Environment and Climate Change Canada is forecasting higher-than-normal temperatures across the country through August.

articles.title: CP NewsAlert: The 2025 wildfire season is on track to be Canada's 2nd-worst on record
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: The area burned by wildfires so far this season is the second-largest on record in Canada, according to the federal government data. More information will come from the Canadian Press later today.      Â  ńŚŚ

articles.title: Study shows NC among states with highest move-in rates in 2025. Asheville drops in ranks
articles.author: Iris Seaton
articles.summary: In 2024, Asheville was one of four North Carolina cities that made it into the top 10 for increased moving rates, joining Wilmington, Charlotte and Raleigh. In 2025, Asheville dropped nearly 10 places following Tropical Storm Helene's effects on the Western N.C. region. In the same year, Wilmington topped the list with the highest number of move-ins, followed by Myrtle Beach.

articles.title: How will the space race affect our environment?
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: In this episode of The Stream, we explore how the race to conquer space will affect the world's environment. Read more Al Jazeera – Breaking News, World News and Video from Al Jazeera here.   .    ...   "The Stream" is an Al Jazeera resource.

articles.title: Rewilding in Highlands threatens culture, land, and lives
articles.author: Alec Iain Poems
articles.summary: They talk of 'rewilding', 'climate goals', but tear the heart from Highland souls. The Danish tycoon, the Russian heir, buy glens like stocks with cold-eyed care. They praise the wild, the noble land, but never lift a working hand. They write the rules and sign the lease.

articles.title: Air quality expected to improve as rain moves through southern Alberta
articles.author: Jodi Hughes
articles.summary: Shift in weather patterns leads to some rain. Jodi Hughes has a look at the five-day forecast from the Sky Watch Weather Centre and shares the forecast with Jodi.    for Jodi and Jodi's Weather Centre on Sky Watch's website.

articles.title: Hot summer coming, forecasters predict
articles.author: Postmedia News
articles.summary: Canada's average summer temperatures have warmed by about 1.8 degrees since 1948. However, strawberry growers say the season is about two weeks later than usual because of cool spring weather. In mid-Ontario, they say the peak of pick-your-own business will be delayed until the end of June, but will likely extend beyond mid-July.

articles.title: High wind advisory discontinued, small craft alert remains
articles.author: Barbados Today
articles.summary: The Barbados Meteorological Services has discontinued the high wind advisory for the island. A small craft advisory remains in effect with moderate winds of 20 to 25 knots and occasional gusts still expected across the country. The advisory will be updated at 6 p.m. or earlier if conditions improve. Beachgoers are advised to swim only at beaches supervised by lifeguards.

articles.title: Hot Summer
articles.author: Editorial Board
articles.summary: There is a heatwave in Kashmir for the second time in the past 30 days. Jammu's temperature has soared to 44.4°C this week, making it one of the hottest places in the world right now. Srinagar, Pahalgam, Gulmarg, and Qazigund are baking under the relentless heat. Kashmir isn't built for this kind of weather. The government has said it's watching the situation. There's talk of an early summer break for schools if things don't improve.

articles.title: Floods and climate resilience: key findings from South Africa's weather-related disasters study
articles.author: Edwin Lombard
articles.summary: Floods and storms are the most recurrent weather-related disasters faced in South Africa. KwaZulu-Natal province is highlighted as the most affected region. The eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality has the highest number of recorded disaster events across the entire country. Urbanisation patterns may play a pivotal role in shaping disaster outcomes. Gauteng reports the fewest droughts.

articles.title: No swim warnings issued for 11 Wicklow bathing areas due to heavy rainfall
articles.author: Eoin Mac Raghnaill
articles.summary: Wicklow County Council has issued an urgent no swim warning at 11 bathing areas up and down the east coast for the next three days due to the possibility of an increase in bacterial levels caused by heavy rainfall and runoff from land and storm overflows. EPA advises beach users to avoid swallowing or splashing water, to wash their hands before handling food, avoid swimming with an open cut or wound and if you are pregnant or have a weakened immune system.

articles.title: As Greenland's ice breaks up, the future of local fishing drifts into further peril
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are posing a growing challenge for the fishing industry in Greenland. Thinning icebergs are becoming too treacherous to fish on or cross. The cod fish without a head costs about 17 Danish kroner. This year, it has been very bad for fishing because of the global warming.

articles.title: How will the space race affect our environment?
articles.summary: Today is World Environment Day. Stefanie Dekker, Eloise Marais, Vishal Prasad and Melanie Hamlett are presenting the show. They discuss the environmental toll of the new space race and climate change on the planet we still call home as well as the cost to our planet.

articles.title: Bhubaneswar to record two-fold increase in heatwave days by 2030
articles.author: Mohammed Imteshal Karim
articles.summary: Bhubaneswar is on track to record a two-fold increase in heatwave days by 2030 due to a deadly combination of heatwaves, extreme humidity, and erratic rainfall. The intensity of extreme rainfall is projected to rise by 43%, making conditions in cities like Bhubaneswar simultaneously hotter and wetter. IMD readings from April 2024 showed humidity levels touching 96% even during non-monsoon nights and daytime temperatures over 40 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: The explosive figure scientists want leaders to know about ocean warming
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Scientists warn the ocean has absorbed heat to match the energy of 1.7 billion atomic bomb explosions since the Paris Agreement. UN Ocean Conference in Nice is addressing these issues. UN Secretary-General António Guterres urges a shift "from plunder to protection" to save the oceans. France's President Emmanuel Macron said the High Seas Treaty could be in force by January 2026.

articles.title: Farmers advised to avoid bushfires to prevent damaging environment
articles.author: Comfort Sena
articles.summary: Farmer advised to stop burning weeds and dry bushes to prevent air pollution and damage to the environment. Mr Emmanuel Boapeng, Project Coordinator, Ghana Shea Landscape and Emissions Reduction Project at Forestry Commission, said bushfires contribute to reducing soil fertility, destroy crops, livestock and habitat for wildlife in forestry reserves. He encouraged farmers to use alternative methods for managing weeds.

articles.title: Why Spain is next in the global fire crisis
articles.author: Tarek Salame
articles.summary: Tarek Salame is concerned about the health risks of wildfire smoke that is spreading across the Atlantic Ocean and into the Spanish skies. The smoke is a chemical cocktail that is laced with arsenic, lead, and other heavy materials from long-abandoned mines. Inhaling them can cause chronic respiratory problems, cardiovascular issues, cancer, and long-term development.

articles.title: Climate change cuts Kashmir cherry yields
articles.summary: Climate change is threatening the livelihoods of cherry farmers in Kashmir. This year's production forecast suggests just 350 to 400 boxes will be harvested, with prices dropping to approximately $0.72 per kilogram. The decline in cherry production adversely impacts transporters, packaging workers, and local sellers. Some farmers are switching to alternative crops.

articles.title: Swiss Re experts warn of growing risks from heatwaves
articles.author: Swi Swissinfo.Ch
articles.summary: There is evidence that the severity, frequency and duration of extreme heatwaves are increasing. Elderly people and pregnant women are particularly at risk. The risk of forest fires in particular has increased in conjunction with strong winds and drought. Forest fires caused insured losses totalling $78.5 billion worldwide between 2015 and 2024.

articles.title: Heat & Mental Health: Expert Explains
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, so does the concern over our mental wellbeing. There is a significant association between increased temperatures and a rise in mental health-related hospitalizations. The relationship between climate change and mental health is complex. People can take preventative steps to protect their mental wellbeing in the face of climate change.

articles.title: COLLINS: Don't open a can of worms
articles.author: Doug Collins
articles.summary: Doug Collins believes that Mother Nature is going to send us a big message about climate change. He believes that we have been fooled for so long by our use of blinders to ignore the mistakes we've made and that we will be the architects of our demise.

articles.title: Oceans have absorbed heat of 1.7 billion atomic bombs, scientists warn as UN summit opens in Nice
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Oceans have absorbed enough heat since the Paris Agreement was signed to match the energy of 1.7 billion atomic bomb explosions every second. Warming is accelerating changes in marine systems, driving sea level rise, sea ice loss and increasing marine heatwaves. UN Ocean Conference is co-hosted this year by France and Costa Rica. It aims to accelerate action to meet global ocean protection targets and finalise voluntary commitments on issues including pollution, overfishing, deep-sea mining and marine biodiversity.

articles.title: Ways to cut down emissions at the store
articles.summary: Cows and other animals like sheep and goats are some of the biggest contributors to emissions, according to the UNFCCC.    .      i   in this article were published and updated.  in the current version of the article, the information has been updated from the previous version.

articles.title: Why the world must help Africa face climate change
articles.author: Dr. Majid Rafizadeh
articles.summary: According to the World Meteorological Organization, extreme weather and climate change impacts are hitting every aspect of socioeconomic development in Africa and exacerbating hunger, insecurity and displacement. Africa's economies are uniquely vulnerable to climate change because they are predominantly reliant on sectors sensitive to weather patterns, especially agriculture, fishing and natural resource extraction. Africa contributes less than 4 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions. Most of the world's emissions come from industrialized nations, especially the US, Europe and China.

articles.title: May 2025 second warmest on record: EU climate monitor
articles.author: Julien MIVIELLE AFP
articles.summary: Last month was the second warmest May on record on land and in the oceans, according to the European Union's climate monitoring service. The global warming is the new norm, according the EU's climate service.       .   in May.

articles.title: Bhubaneswar Faces Double Heatwave Days by 2030, Warns Climate Report
articles.author: Ananya Pattnaik
articles.summary: Bhubaneswar is one of India's most climate-vulnerable cities. The report predicts a two-fold rise in heatwave days by 2030. There is also a 43% projected increase in extreme rainfall events across India by 2030, putting Bhubaneswar at risk of flash floods and heatwaves. The Temple City is already among the most humid cities in India.

articles.title: Crisis Unfolds: Mozambicans Left Vulnerable Amidst Aid Cuts and Conflict
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Mozambique is facing a humanitarian crisis due to conflict and climate change. Over 1.3 million people have been displaced by violence since 2017. UNICEF highlights a children's emergency, as aid budget cuts threaten the wellbeing of impoverished Mozambican children.

articles.title: This Actress Was Loved by Millions but Traded Hollywood for a Farm
articles.author: Gaone Pule
articles.summary: The actress Rachelward left the entertainment industry and now lives on a farm in rural Australia with her husband, Bryan Brown. The family raises regeneratively farmed beef on their small farm in New South Wales. Rachel's Farm was documented in the film "Rachel's Farm" which shows the steps taken to restore the dry soil.

articles.title: Climate change impacts on biological production in the Mediterranean Sea (Universitat de Barcelona)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: In just over 20 years, the northward shift of the subtropical jet stream has been caused by climate change, but it was not related to the phenomenon of jet currents. Climate change impacts on biological production in the Mediterranean Sea, according to the study.

articles.title: PH experienced record-breaking temperatures, 'more than double the average' cyclones from Sept. to Nov. 2024: WMO report
articles.author: Lou Albano
articles.summary: The Philippines experienced extreme weather events as a result of human-induced climate change in 2024. The Department of Agriculture said that damage from El Niño has reached around P3.34 billion. There was a 38.8C temperature at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport on April 27, which is the highest temperature on record for a site in Metro Manila. There were 6 typhoons that hit the Philippines in four weeks between October and November.

articles.title: By 2030 Climate Change Will Significantly Prolong Heatwave Period, Disrupt India's Monsoon Patterns
articles.author: Manasi Kamble
articles.summary: A study presented at the International Global-South Climate Risk Symposium in New Delhi highlights the alarming impact of climate change on India's monsoon patterns and extreme weather events. The study predicts that by 2030, eight out of ten districts in India will face increased occurrences of erratic rainfall and a significant rise in extreme heat incidents.

articles.title: New study reveals disturbing impacts of luxurious lifestyles of the wealthy: 'We can directly link them'
articles.author: Cassidy Lovell
articles.summary: Earth's average global temperature continues to increase. The past decade has featured the highest temperatures since at least the 1800s. Two-thirds of global warming is attributable to the wealthiest 10% of people. Carbon taxes can reduce emissions by disincentivizing high-pollution activities. Fossil fuels are a finite, nonrenewable resource.

articles.title: You're not safe indoors from wildfire smoke. Here's how to smoke-proof your home
articles.author: Kevin Jiang
articles.summary: Toronto's air quality was among the worst in the world last week due to smoke from wildfires burning in Canada's prairie provinces, as Giordano Ciampini reports. The air quality is due to the smoke from the wildfires burning.    The Star

articles.title: 3 B.C. communities broke heat records yesterday
articles.author: Chelsey Mutter
articles.summary: Vernon hit 32.8 C on June 11. The temperature tied the area's daily maximum temperature record, which was previously set in 1969. In all of B.C. only two communities broke heat records. Castlegar in the west Kootenays reached 35.2 C and Clinton in the South Cariboo hit 27.9 C.

articles.title: FAO warns of escalating desert locust threat across North Africa, the Sahel
articles.author: North Africa Post
articles.summary: Desert locust swarms are forming in Libya, Tunisia, and Algeria. They are expected to move southward towards the Sahel in search of rainfall to support breeding. FAO highlights the urgent need for heightened surveillance and control efforts across North Africa. Without decisive intervention, the advancing swarms could lead to large-scale crop devastation.

articles.title: Implement agricultural master plan for Northern Ghana - Women farmers urge govt
articles.summary: Women farmers at a forum called on the government to review and implement an agricultural master plan for Northern Ghana. The forum was held in Bolgatanga in the Upper East Region on the theme: Promoting Sustainable Agriculture for Improved Food Security and Poverty Eradication in Climate-impacted Northern Ghana, The Role of Policy Makers.

articles.title: Australia's COP31 Bid: Action Over Words
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: Australia is lobbying to host the COP31 Climate Negotiations in 2026. It is struggling to meet Renewable Energy Targets, its key industrial emissions policy is flawed, and support for the Fossil Fuel Industry remains strong. Its 43% Emission Reduction Target falls short of the Paris Agreement's Goal To Limit Global Warming To 1.5C.

articles.title: Effects of the changing climate on Jamaica
articles.author: Ricardo Smith
articles.summary: The recent Saharan dust plume in Jamaica raised health issues for those with respiratory problems. The Earth's average temperature is creeping up due to human actions like deforestation and burning fossil fuels. Urban development is messing with forests and green areas. The combination of environmental shifts and rising temperatures poses serious issues that need serious attention and policy changes.

articles.title: Severe heatwave hits Pakistan: Temperatures soar to 48°C in Cholistan and 46°C in Sibi
articles.author: Attia Naveed
articles.summary: Severe heat has engulfed many parts of Pakistan. The Cholistan Desert is experiencing extreme heat. Locals report that water reserves have dried up, causing serious problems for livestock. Lahore recorded temperatures of 44°C, but it felt as high as 47°C due to the heatwave. Quetta, Gwadar, Loralai, Khuzdar, Turbat and Sibi also face high temperatures.

articles.title: Ottana the hottest center in Europe over the weekend: around 41 degrees in June
articles.author: the forecast
articles.summary: Italy sets new negative records on the climate front. Over the weekend a large area of southern Sardinia will reach 40 degrees and the municipality of Ottana, in the Nuoro area, will be the hottest in Europe, reaching 41 degrees. The thermal anomalies of the Mediterranean Sea influence the meteorology of the countries in the area.

articles.title: federal funding cuts Archives
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: Louisiana parishes are bracing themselves for the 2025 Atlantic Hurricane season. President Donald Trump's administration wants to phase out the Federal Emergency Management Agency following the current year. The primary obligation for disaster relief and disaster relief would be transferred to Vermilion Parish.

articles.title: Across P.E.I., wildfire crews are taking extra steps to prepare for whatever the season brings
articles.summary: Environment Canada projects a hotter summer on P.E.I. and other parts of Atlantic Canada. Officials say massive wildfires are rare on the Island. Crews are preparing to make sure they are ready for anything, as CBC's Sheehan Desjardins reports.

articles.title: Floods ravage 180,000 farms across 30 states
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: Nigeria's agricultural sector has been severely impacted by climate change and growing insecurity. Widespread flooding has affected more than 30 states, according to a new report by SBM Intelligence. Click here to read the full report.    ...

articles.title: Netherlands may face arctic winters if ocean current collapses
articles.author: Hanneke Sanou
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is a system of ocean currents that helps keep north-western Europe relatively warm. If AMOC shuts down, winter temperatures in the Netherlands and other parts of northern Europe could plummet, despite global warming continuing overall.

articles.title: Red alert issued for Coastal Karnataka as heavy rains forecast
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: A red alert has been issued for the coastal districts of Karnataka from June 12 to 14. There is a possibility of heavy rainfall, thunderstorms and strong winds. A 24x7 District Emergency Operations Centre has been activated at the DC's office to monitor the situation and respond to distress calls. Fishermen have been prohibited from venturing into the sea during the alert period. Tourists are advised not to enter rivers or beaches until the weather stabilises. People in flood-prone areas are encouraged to shift to designated care centres.

articles.title: Climate Change Hits Mediterranean Sea's Biological Output
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The northward shift of the subtropical jet stream caused by climate change has reduced primary production in the northwestern Mediterranean by about 40%. This reduction affects the base of the marine food web and could significantly impact living resources, ecosystem health and marine dynamics in this region of the Mediterranean.

articles.title: How Heatwaves Damage Your Eye Health And What You Can Do
articles.author: Simran Sukhnani
articles.summary: As the temperature rises, many states are issuing heatwave alerts and urging people to stay inside the house. Heatwaves cause dehydration, heatstroke and skin problems. Studies show that extreme heat also causes damage to our eyes. UV radiation can cause photokeratitis, photograffiti, phototoxemia and phototoxic eye conditions.

articles.title: The 2025 UN Ocean Conference: A global response
articles.author: The Assam Tribune
articles.summary: The oceans cover 71% of the Earth's surface and hold around 97% of its water. They have an enormous impact on global weather, temperature, and food supply to all living organisms. They absorb carbon and release oxygen and regulate global climate patterns. The 2025 United Nations Ocean Conference, co-hosted by France and Costa Rica, is taking place in Nice, France. Key issues under discussion are the Marine Biodiversity Treaty Agreement, decarbonising ocean vessels and controlling plastic pollution.

articles.title: U.N.: Southwest Pacific Hit by Unprecedented Heat Waves in 2024
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Unprecedented heat waves in the Southwest Pacific affected more than 10% of the global ocean surface in 2024, damaging coral reefs and putting the region's last remaining tropical glacier at risk of extinction. Average 2024 temperatures in the region were nearly 0.5 C higher than the 1991-2020 mean. New temperature highs were set in the Philippines and Australia.

articles.title: EU meteorologists recorded decrease in rate of climate warming
articles.summary: For the first time in almost two years, the average air temperature near the planet's surface did not exceed the Paris Agreement target of 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels in May. May 2025 was the second hottest fifth month on record, but the average temperature was 15.79°C – 1.4°C below the target.

articles.title: Planet-friendly shopping goes beyond meat
articles.author: news@pressenterprise.net
articles.summary: The U.N. estimates about a third of the world's greenhouse gas is caused by humans. It's one of the most impactful climate decisions we make every day and we make it multiple times a day. It is important because it's a greenhouse gas.

articles.title: Earth's Air Is Now More Polluted Than Ever Before in Human History
articles.author: Sher Alam
articles.summary: The concentration of carbon dioxide in Earth's air has reached 430.2 parts per million (ppm) in May 2025. This is the highest level recorded in millions of years. The measurement was taken at NOAA's Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii and shows an increase of 3.5 ppm over the past year. Scientists warn it poses a growing threat to human health and planet's stability.

articles.title: Heatwaves and wildfires: Canada's summer forecast reads like a climate horror story
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Canada is bracing for a hotter-than-average summer, particularly in Ontario and the Maritimes. There is potential for major heatwaves and increased temperatures in some parts of the country, especially in Ontario, the Marittimes and Quebec.

articles.title: Effects of the changing climate on Jamaica - Jamaica Observer
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: The climate in Jamaica is changing due to the changing climate. The effects of the climate on Jamaica can be seen here.       in the table below. The table is based on the data from the International Climatology Centre's website.

articles.title: Trump Outlines Strategy to Reduce FEMA Funding
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: President Trump wants to disband FEMA after the 2025 hurricane season. He wants to hand over the responsibility for natural disaster recovery to individual states. Cody McGehe lives in Shore Acres. He got money from FEMA to help rebuild his home. Kevin Batdorf, the president of the Civic Association, wants to hear more about the proposed changes.

articles.title: Rethinking Australia's alliance with Donald Trump's America
articles.author: Mark Beeson
articles.summary: Emma Shortis and Hugh White argue for a reassessment of Australia's relationship with the United States. Shortis is a historian and writer and director of the Australia Institute's International & Security Affairs Program. White is an emeritus professor of strategic studies at the ANU and author of the Australian Defence White Paper in 2000.

articles.title: Greenland ice melted much faster than average in May heatwave
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet melted 17 times faster than the past average during a May heatwave that also hit Iceland. The Arctic region is on the frontline of global warming. In Iceland, the temperature exceeded 26 degrees Celsius (79 Fahrenheit) on May 15, unprecedented for that time of year.

articles.title: MET Service seeking forecasting alternatives to weather Trump cutbacks
articles.summary: Jamaica is bracing for potential fallouts from the Donald Trump administration's funding and job cuts at the primary weather forecasting agency in the United States. This comes amid incomplete repair work on the Doppler weather radar installed in Cooper's Hill, St Andrew, in 2022. The radar has been non-functional since at least March 2022 due to a mechanical defect in the antenna assembly. The repair is scheduled for the final stages later this month and should be completed before July.

articles.title: Orange Alert Issued In Dakshina Kannada District, Schools Shut Amid Heavy Rains Forecast
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: Orange alert has been declared for Dakshina Kannada district due to heavy rainfall. All Anganwadi centres, primary and high schools in the district will be closed on Thursday due to weather-related emergencies. Tourists and locals have been advised to avoid visiting riverbanks and coastal areas.

articles.title: Africa: New Financing to Benefit 1.9 Million Citizens With Enhanced Disaster Preparedness and Response
articles.summary: $300 million credit from the World Bank Group will strengthen disaster preparedness and response capabilities in Tanzania. Tanzania faces increasing exposure to disasters due to its growing population and economy. Recent cyclones, such as Kenneth (2019) and Jobo (2021), along with El-Niño rains and Tropical Cyclone Hidaya (2023-2024), caused 155 deaths, affected over 200,000 people and resulted in $368 million in damages.

articles.title: Paris in peril?
articles.summary: It's the 10th anniversary of the Paris Agreement on climate change. Small island states are urging developed countries to show more commitment to reduce greenhouse emissions. The Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS) has represented the interests of 39 small island and low-lying coastal developing states in international climate change and sustainable development negotiations since 1990.

articles.title: New disaster risk-reduction programme coming for the Caribbean
articles.summary: Jamaica is to benefit from a soon-to-be launched disaster risk-reduction programme for the Caribbean. It includes the offer of grants up to US$500,000 in support of capacity building for scaled up 'policy, institutional and financing mechanisms for resilience recovery'. The announcement comes against the background of the vulnerability of Caribbean small island developing states to the loss and damage associated with climate change impacts.

articles.title: African Women Entrepreneurs Are a Smart Bet for Climate Change Investment
articles.author: Kate Gannon
articles.summary: Women entrepreneurs in Africa are more vulnerable to climate change than men. Their businesses are on the frontline of climate impacts. Women entrepreneurs are key to development outcomes in Africa. They are active in critical agriculture and food processing value chains. They create access points to finance and markets for others in underserved regions. They use their profits to address the most critical household needs. Businesses with women leaders take a more sustainable approach to adaptation than those with only male leaders.

articles.title: Climate change threatens food security as South Africa faces agricultural decline
articles.author: Sibuliso Duba
articles.summary: The impacts of climate change threaten up to a 50% decline in South Africa's agricultural production by 2050. 1 in 5 South Africans live with food insecurity. Food insecurity affected approximately 21% of South African households (approximately 18 million households) in 2021. The National Development Plan (NDP) goals of an 'integrated and inclusive rural economy' and 1 million new jobs in the agricultural sector by 2030 should be realised.

articles.title: May 2025 Was Second Warmest on Record, Climate Service Reports
articles.summary: May 2025 was the second warmest May on record globally, with an average surface temperature of 15.79 degrees Celsius, exceeding the 1991-2020 average by 0.52 degrees, and the pre-industrial 1850-1900 average by 1.4 degrees. The increase did not surpass the 1.5-degree threshold set by the Paris Agreement, but it underscores the ongoing trend of global warming.

articles.title: Women's Cancer Rates are Rising in the Oil Gulf: is Global Heating causing it?
articles.author: Juan Cole
articles.summary: The Middle East is heating up at twice the global average rate and could see a 4°C / 7°F increase over late 19th century averages in only a few decades. The authors found that Gulf women in Bahrain, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the UAE had more cancer as temperatures increased. Qatari women saw increases in all four main types of cancer that distinctively strike women.

articles.title: Arctic heatwave shatters Greenland, Iceland records; could hit monsoons
articles.summary: There was a record-shattering heatwave that sent Greenland's ice sheet melting at 17 times the normal rate due to climate change. May was the second-warmest globally on record, with an average surface air temperature of 15.79°C. The month was 1.4°C above the pre-industrial level and interrupted an extended 21-month period of global temperatures exceeding 1.5°C, according to Copernicus.

articles.title: Heatwaves and wildfires: Canada's summer forecast reads like a climate horror story
articles.summary: Canada is bracing for a hotter-than-average summer, especially in Ontario and the Maritimes, with potential for heatwaves and increased wildfire risk due to dry conditions. Wildfire activity is already surging, with significant hectares burned and widespread evacuations. The smoky impacts are widespread, with air quality alerts issued in Ontario, Quebec, and even parts of the US.

articles.title: June and July may mean flightless geese in your area
articles.author: SUBMITTED
articles.summary: There will be scattered showers and thunderstorms in the afternoon. It will be cloudy and will be 50% chance of rain in the evening. The weather will get cloudy overnight. The temperature will be around 68F with low light and variable winds. The rain will fall 50% of the time.

articles.title: Would a Planetary Sunshade Help Cool the Planet? This Mission Could Find Out
articles.author: Universe Today
articles.summary: As global temperatures continue to rise, governments may turn to geoengineering solutions to deal with the problem, as conventional solutions aren't working fast enough.       .   "Geoengineering" is a form of geoengineering. It is a method of controlling the Earth's temperature.

articles.title: As Australia campaigns for Cop31 hosting rights, it's time to stop talking and start doing ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The 43% emission reduction target is not aligned with the Paris agreement. It should be at least 59%. Australian officials are preparing for next week's climate change conference.       .   "Clear Air" is editor Adam Morton's free newsletter.

articles.title: Trump unveils website for $5 million US residency visa
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: There will be scattered showers and thunderstorms in the afternoon. It will be cloudy and will be 50% chance of rain in the evening. The weather will get cloudy overnight. The temperature will be around 68F with low light and variable winds. The rain will fall 50% of the time.

articles.title: autos Archives
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: In winter, car heating is essential for ensuring a comfortable drive. Misuse of the heating system can lead to increased fuel consumption, reduced vehicle performance and even driver drowsiness. Automotive experts recommend setting the car heater to the optimal temperature.

articles.title: Your city could get twice as hot—India braces for spike in heatwaves and extreme rains
articles.author: Saurav Anand
articles.summary: IPE Global and Esri India have released a report on climate change in India. Eight out of every ten districts in India are set to experience more frequent and intense heatwaves and heavy rains by 2030. Coastal districts, particularly on both eastern and western coasts, are projected to experience extended heat stress during the monsoon season.

articles.title: Experiencing an unusually hot summer? It may be an ‘ELLA' year, Pune study says
articles.author: Neha Madaan
articles.summary: A change in Pacific Ocean patterns can make summers in India feel like the inside of an oven. This dramatic change, from El Niño to La Niña, triggers what the researchers have called 'ELLA years', essentially transition years when the heat can turn up across India, making days and nights hotter, longer, and more unbearable.

articles.title: Trump to phase out FEMA at end of 2025 hurricane season: Here's what the agency actually does and who will feel the impact
articles.author: Jennifer Mattson
articles.summary: Trump wants to phase out the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) after this year's hurricane season. He wants to bring the responsibility for disaster relief down to the state level. The administration has long vowed to "eliminate" FEMA, the nation's key disaster relief agency.

articles.title: EPA says power plant carbon emissions aren't dangerous. We asked 30 scientists: Here's what they say.
articles.summary: 'It's about as valid as saying that arsenic is not a dangerous substance to consume,' said Michael Mann. 'The world is round, the sun rises in the east, coal-and gas-fired power plants contribute to climate change, and climate change increases the risk of heat waves, catastrophic storms, infectious diseases, and many other health threats,' said Dr. Howard Frumkin, former director of the National Center for Environmental Health. 'It's hard to imagine a decision dumber than putting the short-term interests of oil and gas companies ahead of the long-term interest of our children and grandchildren,' said Chris Field.

articles.title: Illegal Fish Farming Devastates Goa's Khazan Lands; State Launches Khazan Board
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: Goa's Khazan lands, once the backbone of Goa's agricultural economy, are under assault. Illegal fish farming operators are deliberately breaching protective bunds to flood fields with saltwater, destroying crops and rendering large tracts of farmland useless. The government has responded with its most ambitious intervention yet. It plans to set up a Khazen Board with overriding authority on land use in khazan areas. The board will be established within six months.

articles.title: Shrinking Indus delta increases risk of floods, experts warn
articles.author: Fact Check Iverify
articles.summary: Experts spoke at a seminar on Climate Risks and Challenges in Sindh: Regional Vulnerabilities, Emissions Control, and Institutional Strategies for Sustainable Action. They called for integrated, climate-resilient development strategies, legal protection for freshwater flows and urgent institutional reforms to restore the ecological balance of the Indus delta. The event was hosted by Sindh Madressatul Islam University (SMIU) and The Knowledge Forum.

articles.title: Greenland ice melted much faster in May heatwave
articles.author: Fact Check Iverify
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet melted 17 times faster than the past average during a May heatwave that also hit Iceland. The Arctic region is on the frontline of global warming. The hottest day during the heatwave was 3.9 degrees Celsius warmer compared to the preindustrial climate.

articles.title: Pakistan, India, Nepal may receive above-average rains
articles.author: Recorder Report
articles.summary: Temperatures are expected to be up to 2°C hotter than average across the whole Hindu Kush Himalayan (HKH) region this summer monsoon. Three countries, India, Nepal, and Pakistan, as well as China's Tibetan autonomous region are also set for above-average rainfall. Floods are the leading cause of deaths and economic damage in the HKH, and close to three-quarters (72.5%) of all floods from 1980 to 2024 occurred during the summer Monsoon season. Experts warn disaster agencies and communities to brace for a possible rise in climate risks and impacts.

articles.title: City may see rise in heatwave days, erratic rain events: Study
articles.summary: Chennai is among eight Indian cities that are likely to see a two-fold increase in heatwave days in the next five years. Climate change is expected to drive a 43% rise in the intensity of extreme rainfall events across India, making it simultaneously hotter and wetter.

articles.title: Seminar on ‘Climate Risks and Challenges in Sindh' held at SMIU
articles.summary: Environmentalists, academics and community activists have called for urgent measures to safeguard the Indus Delta ecosystem and the livelihoods of its fishing communities. The seminar was hosted by Sindh Madressatul Islam University in collaboration with the Knowledge Forum. The speakers highlighted the devastating impact of reduced freshwater flows in the River Indus and the decline in fish stocks and mangrove cover.

articles.title: Arctic blast grips more than 220 million Americans
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: The arctic blast gripping more than 220 million Americans is forecast to bring more cold weather to the area.   Â      i   in the U.S. it's expected to bring a lot more.  in this way.

articles.title: Icy homes: Why most Aussies are using their heaters the wrong way
articles.author: Aidan Devine
articles.summary: Icy mornings remind Aussies that winter is coming. Most Australian homes were never designed with winter comfort in mind. Most households are using heaters in an inefficient way that's sending their power bills through the roof. The average overseas home exceeds a seven-star energy rating, while most Australian homes lag well behind that benchmark.

articles.title: ‘Pretty frigid': Low temperatures affecting most of Australia
articles.summary: It was 6.5 degrees in Brisbane, 7.8 degrees in Sydney and minus 4.6 degrees in Canberra on Saturday. It was the coldest day of the year so far in some parts of Queensland, according to Sky News Australia Meteorologist Alison Osborne.

articles.title: To Shimmer Or Not To Shimmer
articles.author: Jim Kosek
articles.summary: Heat haze is an optical phenomenon that develops when the air near the ground is heated more than its surrounding environment. It can happen this time of year on brighter days, at or just above darker surfaces like pavement, roads, rooftops, or looking at distant objects on the horizon.

articles.title: Climate change may shrink Italy's GDP by over 5 pct by 2050: Budget Office
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Climate-related damage could reduce Italy's gross domestic product by over 5 percent by 2050. Italy's long coastline, water stress, and reliance on agriculture make it particularly vulnerable to climate change. Floods, droughts, wildfires, and heatwaves cut GDP by 0.2 percent in 2023. Meeting carbon neutrality goals could limit the GDP contraction to 0.9 percent.

articles.title: Orange alert issued in Dakshina Kannada district, schools shut
articles.summary: Orange alert has been declared for Dakshina Kannada district due to heavy rainfall. All Anganwadi centres, primary and high schools will be closed on Thursday. Emergency response measures have been activated under the Disaster Management Authority. Public advisory has been issued urging parents to prevent children from venturing near water bodies, low-lying areas, rivers, and the seashore. Fisherfolk have been strictly advised not to venture into the sea.

articles.title: Long-Term Recovery Group's efforts underway
articles.author: The Newport Plain Talk
articles.summary: Cocke County is still working to recover from the flooding caused by the remnants of Hurricane Helene last September. The Cocke County Long-Term Recovery Group (CCLTRG) is working hard to make that process go as smoothly as possible. CCLTRG is a volunteer organization.

articles.title: Aukus: US to review submarine pact as part of
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: It comes as Australia faces pressure from the White House to dramatically lift its military spending. It is expected to increase it from $20 billion to $30 billion.    in the next few years. It's expected to be a source of tension with the US.

articles.title: Number of Australians who identify as gay, bi or trans doubles
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: The number of Australians who identify as LGBTQ+ has doubled in the past eight years. The LGB+ population of Australia doubled between 2012 and 2020, increasing from 3.3% of adults over the age of 15 to 5.8%. The study was led by Charles Darwin University.

articles.title: US reviewing Aukus submarine pact as part of 'America First' agenda
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: It comes as Australia faces pressure from the White House to dramatically lift its military spending. It is expected to increase it from $20 billion to $30 billion.    in the next few years. It's expected to be a source of tension between Washington and Canberra.

articles.title: Greenland ice melted much faster in May heatwave
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet melted 17 times faster than the past average during a May heatwave that also hit Iceland. The Arctic region is on the frontline of global warming, heating up four times faster that the rest of the world. The Greenland ice sheet contribution to sea level rise is higher than it would have otherwise been without this heat wave.

articles.title: Sea Level Rise 2025 Workshop Shows Malaysia's Commitment To Tackling Climate Change
articles.author: Malaysian National News Agency
articles.summary: Malaysia is hosting the two-day ASEAN Workshop on Sea. It's a show of Malaysia's commitment to tackling climate change. It will take place on 11-06-2025 in Kuala Lumpur and 7-7 June in Bernama.

articles.title: Islam Fastest-Growing In World, Christianity 2nd, 'Nones' 3rd Largest: Pew Report
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: Pew's report on the Global Religious Landscape was published on June 9. It shows how population growth has influenced the global religious landscape and how religion is affected by it. It says that religion is influenced by population growth and religion by population change.

articles.title: Geomagnetic Storms Bring Satellites Down Faster
articles.author: Universe Today
articles.summary: When the Sun rages and storms in Earth's direction, it changes the planet's atmosphere. The atmosphere puffs up, meaning Earth's atmosphere is getting warmer and more active than usual.       .   ,   in the Sun's direction.

articles.title: May 2025 Was Second Warmest on Record, Climate Service Reports
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: May 2025 was the second warmest May on record globally, with an average surface temperature of 15.79 degrees Celsius. May 2025 exceeded the 1991-2020 average by 0.52 degrees and the pre-industrial 1850-1900 average by 1.4 degrees.

articles.title: Greta Thunberg suffers ‘one final embarrassment' in deportation from Israel
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg landed from being deported by Israel. Andrew Bolt discusses Greta's 'one final embarrassment' as she landed from Israel's deportation of her from the US.    Google Alert – Israel. Google Alert is a Google Alert.

articles.title: May 2025 second warmest on record: EU climate monitor
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Last month was the second warmest May on record on land and in the oceans, according to the European Union's climate monitoring service. The planet's average surface temperature dipped below the threshold of 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. The same held for the world's oceans with a surface temperature of 20.79C.

articles.title: ‘ग्रिनल्यान्डको हिउँ औसतभन्दा धेरै छिटो पग्ल्यो'
articles.author: रासस/एएफपी
articles.summary: samsung_banner_wrapper, Samsung's ad, is a text file with a number of different sizes. It contains the text 'samsung.banner' and the image 'sans-caption'. It also contains a number with the number 'caution'.

articles.title: Enough is enough
articles.summary: Dave Cree Hassig and Colton are concerned about a worsening climate crisis. They ask when will we ask self-sacrifice of ourselves enough to seriously reduce our own excessive per capita consumption of natural resources. They are concerned that as a 'more-for-me' worldview goes global, the cumulative weight of our species' environmental wreckage will become an ever-more oppressive burden to the earth.

articles.title: May 2025 second warmest on record: EU climate monitor
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Global heating is the new norm. Last month the temperature increased by 0.5 degrees Celsius.    Last month was the warmest month on record for the whole world. The previous month it was the coldest month since 2008, according to the WHO.

articles.title: This could be Canada's 2nd-worst wildfire season
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: The area burned by wildfires in Canada so far this season is the second-largest on record for this time of year, according to government data. The area burned so far is also the second largest on record this far into the year, after the previous year.

articles.title: I was excited to come to Australia on a working holiday visa - but here's ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Alice Carter moved from London to Sydney four months ago. She is worried she will be forced to return to the UK as she can't find a job in Australia and she's afraid she will have to return home.    Alice shares one of the biggest struggles she's been faced with since moving to Australia.

articles.title: Russian Scientists Find New Island In Caspian Sea But Couldn't Land On It
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: The island appeared because of a fall in the water level of the sea due to climate change, which caused a rise in the sea level. The rise in sea level caused by climate change is due to the fall in water levels of the ocean. The sea level is rising due to sea level rise.

articles.title: Climate models with low sensitivity to greenhouse gases do not align with satellite measurements
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Climate models that give a low warming from increases in greenhouse gases do not, according to the IPCC. The IPCC's climate models do not predict a rise in greenhouse gas emissions.       for this reason, the IPCC's models are wrong.

articles.title: Live in a hurricane-prone area? Here's how to prepare your home for flooding
articles.author: National Public Radio
articles.summary: There are ways to harden your home with flooding and climate change in mind to prevent flooding during hurricane season this year. Chandan Khanna shares some of them with you here. For more information, go to: http://www.chandankhanna.com/how-to-harden-your-home.

articles.title: Across P.E.I., wildfire crews are taking extra steps to prepare for whatever the season brings
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Environment Canada is projecting a hotter summer than usual on P.E.I. and many other parts of the Atlantic region.       "It's going to be warmer than usual in many parts of Atlantic region."  "In some places it will be hotter than usual.

articles.title: Why the world must help Africa face climate change
articles.author: Arab News
articles.summary: According to the World Meteorological Organization, extreme weather and climate change impacts are hitting every aspect of socioeconomic development in Africa and exacerbating hunger, insecurity and displacement. This statement underscores the scale of devastation sweeping across the continent as it faces the climate change and extreme weather.

articles.title: USDA Extends Emergency Conservation and Emergency Forest Restoration Assistance Deadline for Hurricane Recovery in Florida (FSA - Farm Service Agency)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The deadline for two critical hurricane recovery programs has been extended to June 12, 2025. The Emergency Conservation Program (ECP) provides cost-share and technical assistance to producers to restore farmland to pre-disaster state.      .

articles.title: Record high temperatures hit Greenland and Iceland, Copernicus Observatory warns
articles.summary: Greenland experienced a melting rate 17 times faster than average last month due to record-high temperatures. Iceland saw temperatures exceed 26°C. May 2025 was the second warmest May on record with a global average surface air temperature of 15.79°C, 0.53°C above the 1991-2020 average. This marked 21 of the last 22 months exceeding the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C threshold. Droughts affected regions like North America, Africa, Central Asia, southern Australia, and South America.

articles.title: In Depth: Project to Beat Back the Sahara Struggles to Take Root, Even With Chinese Expertise
articles.author: Kang Jia
articles.summary: Africa's Sahel region is home to more than 140 million people. The region has endured three major droughts over the past century. As of 2022, 278 million Africans were undernourished, according to the U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization.

articles.title: EC flooding: Cabinet expresses condolences to families who've lost loved ones
articles.author: Primedia
articles.summary: 57 people have died due to flooding and extreme weather in the Eastern Cape. Several families have been displaced and infrastructure damaged. Khumbudzo Ntshavheni, Minister in The Presidency, delivered the message during a post-Cabinet briefing in Cape Town on Thursday.

articles.title: World emissions added ‘heat equivalent of 1.7 billion atomic bombs to ocean' since 2015 Paris Agreement, say scientists
articles.author: Vibha Sharma
articles.summary: World added the energy equivalent of nearly two billion atom bombs to the ocean since the Paris Agreement was signed in 2015. Global warming over the last 10 years equates to about 1.7 billion atomic bomb explosions. Global sea ice hit an all-time low this year, sea surface temperatures in 2024 smashed previous records, and 84% of coral reef areas bleached.
